title: 106_hr1625
content: The Act may be cited as the "Human Rights Information Act". It includes findings related to human rights. Congress finds that the national and international protection of human rights is a key value in democracy, with federal agencies holding documents on human rights violations abroad. Requests for legal assistance on human rights violations, including declassification of documents, are expected from foreign authorities. The United States responds to declassification requests for information on General Augusto Pinochet by following procedures outlined in Presidential directives and executive orders. Strengthening declassification procedures is crucial for protecting and promoting human rights globally, ensuring accountability of Federal agencies, and saving Government resources. This commitment aligns with the promotion and protection of human rights and democracy worldwide. The United States actively promotes human rights and democracy globally through diplomatic, economic, and military efforts. It is crucial for newly established democratic societies to investigate and prosecute human rights violations to prevent the cycle of impunity. This commitment aligns with the promotion and protection of human rights and democracy worldwide. The United States has long provided international leadership to end impunity for gross human rights violations and promote the rule of law by supporting various war crimes tribunals. The US has ratified the Convention against Torture and should seek to follow recommendations for criminal proceedings related to torture. The United States should adopt measures to ensure free access to information in cases of investigations for international crimes and human rights violations, as recommended by the Inter-American Commission on Human Rights. Despite the investigation by the Clarification Commission in Guatemala, many questions regarding human rights violations remain unanswered. The Clarification Commission recommended utilizing all resources to clarify the whereabouts of disappeared individuals and deliver remains to relatives. Two days after presenting the "Guatemala: Never Again" investigation, Bishop Juan Jose Gerardi was assassinated. President Clinton acknowledged past support for repressive military forces in Guatemala and pledged to support peace and reconciliation. The National Commissioner for the Protection of Human Rights is involved in the process. The National Commissioner for the Protection of Human Rights in Honduras has been requesting documentation from the United States on human rights violations since November 15, 1993. The request has been partially fulfilled, but some aspects are still pending. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. This Act defines key terms such as "human rights record," "agency," and "gross violations of internationally recognized human rights." SEC. 4 of the Act governs the declassification and public disclosure of human rights records regarding Guatemala and Honduras after 1944. Agencies must identify, review, and organize these records for public disclosure within 30 days of completion. The President must report to Congress on agency compliance within 150 days. An agency can delay public disclosure of a human rights record if there is clear evidence that the threat to national security outweighs the public interest. This includes protecting intelligence agents, sources, or methods that are crucial for ongoing operations. The public disclosure of a human rights record can be delayed if it would impair national security, reveal confidential sources, invade personal privacy, or compromise confidentiality agreements. The disclosure of a human rights record can be postponed if it would harm national security or reveal confidential sources, even if the individual named was an intelligence asset of the US government. SEC. 6. REQUEST FOR HUMAN RIGHTS RECORDS FROM OFFICIAL ENTITIES IN OTHER COUNTRIES. When a US agency receives a request for human rights records from certain international entities or countries investigating human rights violations, they must review and disclose the records according to the standards in this Act. SEC. 7. REVIEW OF DECISIONS TO WITHHOLD RECORDS. The Appeals Panel reviews agency determinations to postpone public disclosure of human rights records. They direct disclosure unless there is clear evidence that the record is not a human rights record or qualifies for postponement. If they agree to postpone disclosure, they consult with the agency. The Appeals Panel reviews agency determinations regarding the disclosure of human rights records. They consider alternative forms of disclosure, such as disclosing a summary of the information contained in the record. After completing their review, the Appeals Panel notifies the agency head of their determination within 14 days. The Appeals Panel reviews agency determinations on human rights record disclosure and notifies the President. The President has the authority to review and disclose the determination based on set standards within 30 days. The President must provide the Appeals Panel with a written certification of the decision on human rights record disclosure, including reasons and standards. The Appeals Panel will publish any materials related to the postponement of disclosure in the Federal Register. SEC. 8. The Information Security Policy Advisory Council will report to Congress on declassifying human rights records of other countries. SEC. 9. Ensures the Freedom of Information Act and judicial review rights are not limited. SEC. 10. Creation of positions. SEC. 10. Creation of 2 additional positions in the Appeals Panel for individuals with substantial human rights expertise appointed by the President with recommendations from human rights organizations.
